title: 030 Pitfall - Thread creation is relatively expensive
The first benchmark simply creates, starts and joins threads. The thread’s

title: On a typical modern PC running Linux with 64bit Java 8 u101, this benchmark shows an average time taken to create, start and join thread of between 33.6 and 33.9 microseconds.

inline_content.Text: On a typical modern PC running Linux with 64bit Java 8 u101, this benchmark shows an average time taken to create, start and join thread of between 33.6 and 33.9 microseconds.

title: The second benchmark does the equivalent to the first but using an
ExecutorService
c
to submit tasks and a
Future
c
to rendezvous with the end of the task.

inline_content.Text: The second benchmark does the equivalent to the first but using an
to rendezvous with the end of the task.

title: As you can see, the averages are between 5.3 and 5.6 microseconds.

inline_content.Text: As you can see, the averages are between 5.3 and 5.6 microseconds.

title: While the actual times will depend on a variety of factors, the difference between these two results is significant. It is clearly faster to use a thread pool to recycle threads than it is to create new threads.

inline_content.Text: While the actual times will depend on a variety of factors, the difference between these two results is significant. It is clearly faster to use a thread pool to recycle threads than it is to create new threads.
